One measure of tone mapping is the exposure value, whose effect on the output is similar to that of the shutter speed (or exposure time) of a real-world camera—lower exposure values result in a darker image, and higher exposures result in a brighter image. You cannot adjust exposure value directly—instead, SceneKit determines a tone mapping curve (including the exposure level) from the [doc://com.apple.scenekit/documentation/SceneKit/SCNCamera/minimumExposure], [doc://com.apple.scenekit/documentation/SceneKit/SCNCamera/maximumExposure], [doc://com.apple.scenekit/documentation/SceneKit/SCNCamera/exposureOffset], and [doc://com.apple.scenekit/documentation/SceneKit/SCNCamera/whitePoint] properties along with a measure of scene luminance.

# wantsExposureAdaptation

**Instance Property**

A Boolean value that determines whether SceneKit automatically adjusts the exposure level.

## Declaration

```swift
var wantsExposureAdaptation: Bool { get set }
```

## Discussion

When using a High Dynamic Range (HDR) camera, SceneKit applies a process called *tone mapping* to translate the wide range of luminance values in the visible scene to the narrower range of brightness values that can be shown on a display. One measure of tone mapping is the exposure value, whose effect on the output is similar to that of the shutter speed (or exposure time) of a real-world camera—lower exposure values result in a darker image, and higher exposures result in a brighter image. You cannot adjust exposure value directly—instead, SceneKit determines a tone mapping curve (including the exposure level) from the [doc://com.apple.scenekit/documentation/SceneKit/SCNCamera/minimumExposure], [doc://com.apple.scenekit/documentation/SceneKit/SCNCamera/maximumExposure], [doc://com.apple.scenekit/documentation/SceneKit/SCNCamera/exposureOffset], and [doc://com.apple.scenekit/documentation/SceneKit/SCNCamera/whitePoint] properties along with a measure of scene luminance.

If this property’s value is [doc://com.apple.documentation/documentation/Swift/true] (the default), SceneKit automatically measures the current luminance visible to the camera during rendering, and adjusts the exposure level accordingly. Additionally, when the scene luminance changes, SceneKit automatically animates a transition to the new exposure level (see the [doc://com.apple.scenekit/documentation/SceneKit/SCNCamera/exposureAdaptationBrighteningSpeedFactor] and [doc://com.apple.scenekit/documentation/SceneKit/SCNCamera/exposureAdaptationDarkeningSpeedFactor] properties).



If this property’s value is [doc://com.apple.documentation/documentation/Swift/false], SceneKit’s tone mapping effect is constant. Instead of responding to scene luminance, SceneKit uses the [doc://com.apple.scenekit/documentation/SceneKit/SCNCamera/averageGray] property to determine the tone mapping curve.

This property has no effect if the [doc://com.apple.scenekit/documentation/SceneKit/SCNCamera/wantsHDR] value is [doc://com.apple.documentation/documentation/Swift/false].

## Adding Automatic HDR Exposure Adaptation

- **exposureAdaptationBrighteningSpeedFactor**: The relative duration of automatically animated exposure transitions from dark to bright areas.
- **exposureAdaptationDarkeningSpeedFactor**: The relative duration of automatically animated exposure transitions from bright to dark areas.
